docs.lead_paragraph: TWO years ago, Juliette Binoche came to New York with the script for ''Chocolat'' in hand, and the starring role for herself in mind. She sat down with Harvey Weinstein, the larger-than-life power behind Miramax Films, whom she already knew was planning to produce the film, and told him how much she loved the part. ''I was kind of astonished by his reaction,'' Ms. Binoche recalled recently. ''He said, 'Well, Juliette, if you really want to do it, then you have to ask for it.' So I said, 'Harvey, may I do this film?' And it's funny, but it was a very good experience for me, because making a demand is very clarifying. I think in life you have to ask for things to happen. They don't just pop out of a box.''
docs.abstract: Jennet Conant interview with Juliette Binoche on her hit movie Chocolat and upcoming film The Widow of Saint-Pierre; photos (M)

docs.snippet: IT'S hard to imagine anyone but Tom Hanks playing the prison-guard protagonist of THE GREEN MILE (1999). Even death row was a gentler, more humane place during the Depression in this film, written and directed by Frank Darabont and based on the se...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT'S hard to imagine anyone but Tom Hanks playing the prison-guard protagonist of THE GREEN MILE (1999). Even death row was a gentler, more humane place during the Depression in this film, written and directed by Frank Darabont and based on the serial novel by Stephen King. Michael Clarke Duncan is heart-wrenching as the gentle giant of prisoner who calls all the guards ''boss,'' is afraid of the dark, protects even the tiniest of god's creatures and yet has been convicted of the rape and murder of two little girls. Gradually the men around the prisoner come to believe in his literally miraculous healing powers and his innocence. Mr. Hanks, as is his gift, comes across as decency personified -- Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

docs.lead_paragraph: Guyana's undefeated Andrew Lewis, known as Six Heads, captured the vacant World Boxing Association welterweight title tonight, stopping James Page of the United States in the seventh round at the MGM Grand Hotel. Lewis, who lives in Crown Heights in Brooklyn, became Guyana's first boxing world champion, rising to 20-0 with one draw after his 19th early stoppage, which came 73 seconds into Round 7. Page, in his first bout after a 19-month layoff, fell to 25-4.

docs.snippet: Rational -- and irrational -- people may differ over the merits of Bill Clinton's presidency, but few can dispute that he was without peer as our entertainer in chief. He turned the whole citizenry, regardless of ideology or demographic, into dram...
docs.lead_paragraph: Rational -- and irrational -- people may differ over the merits of Bill Clinton's presidency, but few can dispute that he was without peer as our entertainer in chief. He turned the whole citizenry, regardless of ideology or demographic, into drama fiends. When he left office, the cliché had it that late-night comics, after eight years of sure-fire punch lines, would miss him the most. Now it turns out we're all junkies for the fast-paced, round-the-clock theatrics that defined the Clinton years, and we're desperate for a fix, any fix, to fill the cultural vacuum he left behind. Thus do we hope against hope that Arlen Specter may be right and that it may actually be possible for Congress to impeach Mr. Clinton again, preferably at great length. We prayed as well that New York's mayor would not relinquish the city's claim on the former president's new Harlem office space, setting the stage for the Clinton-Giuliani bloodbath we were so cruelly denied in 2000. We even dream that Mr. Clinton will testify about the Marc Rich pardon before Dan Burton's committee, and, for old times' sake, help that wacky congressman revive those graphic re-enactments he once conducted of the ''murder'' of Vincent Foster.
docs.abstract: Frank Rich Op-Ed column says Americans have grown addicted to combative politics and entertainment during Clinton years and Pres Bush and his agenda could well fall victim to turmoil Bill Clinton continues to stir; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Oscar De La Hoya has scored a legal decision over HBO that will allow him to fight Arturo Gatti on March 24 in a match that now can be televised by another network. It was disclosed yesterday by Bernard Nussbaum, a lawyer representing De La Hoya, that the federal judge Victor Marrero ruled against HBO. The cable network was seeking to enjoin the fight or to allow it to be televised only by HBO.

docs.lead_paragraph: KALENDER-Gloria. On February 15, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Stanley Kalender and Monroe Haspel. Adored mother of Candyce Brokaw. Cherished grandmother of Morgan, Ashley and Courtney Brokaw. Dear, devoted sister to Jean and Sid Kaufman, Barbara Schwartz and the late Gene Schwartz. Daughter of the late Henrietta and Oscar Baer. Survived by loving nieces and nephews Toni Schwartz, Doug Schwartz, Terri Kaufman and Jill and Rick Kaufman. Gloria will be remembered for her lively spirit, style and wit and her nurturing and loving nature. She was deeply loved and admired by all. She will be sadly missed. Services Sunday, February 18, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. The family will receive guests at the home of Gloria Kalender on Sunday from 3:307:30PM.
